Award.AwardTitle: Environment-Agent Interaction in Autonomous Networked Teams with Applications to Minimum-Time Coordinated Control of Multi-Agent Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop motion coordination and path-planning algorithms for small/micro unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs/MAVs) using appropriate, state-dependent performance metrics that capture the interactions of the vehicle with the environment, the mission objectives, as well as the system-theoretic attributes of the network. The environment includes both the ambient conditions (e.g., winds) as well as the actual, or perceived, adversarial behavior of any opponents operating in the vicinity of the vehicle. A key concept that will play a major role in developing these results will be the generalized (Zermelo) Voronoi diagrams which can capture the dynamics of the state of the agents in the network (e.g., estimated-time-of-arrival, path curvature constraints) much better than traditional Voronoi diagrams that are based solely on Euclidean distance. With the help of these diagrams, the proximity relations between different agents and/or between the agents and a set of targets will be characterized, and decentralized and distributed control strategies will be developed.

If successful, the results of this research will enable small-scale autonomous aerial, marine or underwater vehicles to operate in teams towards a common objective such as environmental monitoring, distributed surveillance, multiple target allocation, coordinated target pursuit, etc. in the presence of locally strong winds or currents and with limited on-board power and computational resources. Owing to their small size, the trajectories of these aerial platforms are strongly influenced by the prevailing winds, as well as the limitations imposed by the available on-board resources. The tools to be developed in this research will also find application in other areas of networked controlled systems, where intelligent agents must cooperate to perform their mission, a task that would be infeasible if it were to be undertaken by a single member of the team. Graduate and undergraduate engineering students as well as local high school teachers will benefit from their involvement in this research through NSF?s REU and RET projects and through Georgia Tech?s PURA and Dash undergraduate research fellowship programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the recent years there has been an ever increasing emphasis on the use of autonomous aerial or marine/underwater vehicles for monitoring, inspection, product delivery etc. During natural disasters (e.g., earthquakes, floods) and man-made accidents (e.g., Malaysian airlines flight MH370) alike these autonomous vehicles have proven to be indispensable during search and rescue missions. Drones have also been used extensively by law enforcement and military entities. The objective of this research has been the investigation of the effect of the winds (for the case of aerial vehicles) or sea currents (for the case of marine or underwater vehicles) in the motion of these vehicles. Taking environmental effect into consideration when one tries to find optimal control and trajectories   can lead to time and/or fuel savings. Both single agent and multi-agent teams have been investigated. Using tools from computational geometry (Voronoi partitions) we have been able to identify the “regions of responsibility” for each agent. This has allowed us to provide decentralized solutions to the problem that scale nicely with the number of participating agents. We have extended the results to the case of adversarial agents operating inside a dynamic field and we have provided both semi-analytic and purely numerical solutions to solve problems such as optimal time-to-intercept as well as collision avoidance problems. The results of this research can have a profound effect to the scheduling and operation of large teams of autonomous agents. This work will also have an immediate impact on the industry specializing in UAV/UUV/UGV technology and on embedded, networked control systems.  It will allow the running of highly sophisticated algorithms inside the "brain" of these autonomous systems, thus increasing their performance. The market for autonomous ground, aerial and sea vehicles has witnessed an enormous growth during the past decade and it is currently estimated to be in excess of $8 billion. By adding environmental effect as one of the factors of the decision making of these autonomous systems, we expect to increase their reliability and fail-safe operation.
